title: Improved Measures of the Family Environment in Longitudinal Population Studies of Child Health in Sub-Saharan Africa
abstractText:
The aim of this project is to answer the question: Can measurement and analyses of family determinants of child health and wellbeing be improved in longitudinal, population-based studies in sub-Saharan Africa? The focus of our empirical work are data collected in the tri-annual Africa Centre for Health and Population Studies demographic surveillance system (DSS) in rural KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa. The objectives of the project are to:

  • identify instruments to measure key indicators of the family environment that can be feasibly implemented in ongoing longitudinal or repeated cross-sectional population studies in sub-Saharan Africa
  • test different strategies for collecting data about families, including information about non-resident parents, non-parental caregiving and geographically mobile children
  • evaluate the validity and reliability of family data obtained from multiple respondents
  • incorporate multiple and dynamic family risk environments in statistical analyses to identify determinants of child health and wellbeing
  • contribute improved measurement tools and detailed data to inform the design and evaluation of new family oriented child health interventions.
